Template.phase_banner: This is a new service - your <feedback>feedback</feedback> will help us to improve it.

nsoc.title: National Space Operations Centre Civil Warning and Protection Services
nsoc.content: National Space Operations Centre (NSpOC) Civil Warning and Protection Services support UK and international partners to manage space risks and hazards.

list_items.statistics: Explore key statistics for UK space hazards

new_users.title: New users
new_users.markup:
We provide monthly reports on space risks and hazards which are accessible to everyone (National Space Operations Centre) and regularly updated space weather information is available from our partner the Met Office.

At this time, access to the operational services provided by Monitor Space Hazards is available to UK licensed satellite operators and UK Government departments. If you meet these criteria and would like access, please contact monitorspacehazards@ukspaceagency.gov.uk.

Visit National Space Operations Centre for further information about our services.

Dashboard.title: UK space warning and protection services
Dashboard.content: National Space Operations Centre (NSpOC) Civil Warning and Protection Services support UK and international partners to manage space risks and hazards.

view_terms_and_conditions.title: View terms and conditions and data privacy notice

Contact_and_organisation_information.if_your_contact_details_are_incorrect: if your contact details are incorrect.

Terms_and_conditions.title: View Terms and Conditions
Terms_and_conditions.accepted_text: By using Monitor Space Hazards you have agreed to the Terms and Conditions of the site.
Terms_and_conditions.label: I have read and agreed to the Terms and Conditions

Contact_analyst.title: Operations support
Contact_analyst.content:
NSpOC orbital analysts are available Monday to Sunday, 8am to 4pm. Your message will be triaged and an analyst will get back to you as soon as possible.

NSpOC orbital analysts can provide:

Further detail on their calculationsAn indication on whether further analysis of an event is possible

NSpOC orbital analysts cannot provide:

Advice on how you should manoeuvre your satelliteAnalysis on a planned manoeuvre
Contact_analyst.event_id: Conjunction event ID or Re-entry event ID

Send.title: Your message has been sent to an orbital analyst.
Send.content: Your message will be triaged and an analyst will get back to you as soon as possible.

Credentials.title: Credentials for API authentication
Credentials.warning: Copy your Client ID and Client Secret to authenticate with the API. Do not share your credentials.

Event_notification_thresholds_settings.title: Set your conjunction event notification thresholds
Event_notification_thresholds_settings.content:
We will send you notifications when the probability of collision, total miss distance and mean radial miss distance meets threshold and the time to conjunction event is below the threshold you have set.

You are responsible for the safe operation of your satellites and should choose settings which allow you to do this.

The default settings are examples of thresholds, not recommendations.

Notification_settings.title: Choose your notification settings
Notification_settings.content:
New event notifications will be collated and sent in one email and/or SMS every 12 hours.

Choose which notifications you wish to receive. Uncheck boxes where you do not wish to receive notifications.

Add_new_user.title: Add a new user
Add_new_user.content: Add a new user to join your organisation by entering the details below. New users will receive an invitation to the email address specified.

Incident_banners.title: Manage incident banners
Incident_banners.content:
In the case of an incident, the Monitor Space Hazards service will remain live, but it is important to notify all Monitor Space Hazards users.

Super users are able to display banners that will be visible at the top of each page, warning users that the information presented on Monitor Space Hazards may not be accurate.

banner.success_message: The user has been deleted from {organisationName} organisation

Organisation_user.description: Update a user's information by editing the details below.

type_change.warning: Changing account type will change the permissions associated with this account.

banner.title: Are you sure you want to delete this user?

Setup.review_terms_and_conditions: Review terms and conditions and data privacy notice

notification.completed: You have completed account set up. You can now access the site.
notification.uncompleted: You must review and complete all sections of account set up before you can access the service.

Distribution_lists.title: View distribution lists
Distribution_lists.description: We will send notifications according to the distribution lists outlined on this page.

conjunctions_help.content:
Standard conjunction alert

There are various criteria which determine if alerts are produced about conjunction events. These criteria vary by type of object.

For UK-licensed objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest ApproachMore than 0.1% probability of collisionPress interest

For non-UK objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:Low risk or higherNo manoeuvre expected

For all objects:

If nominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority conjunction alert

For UK-licensed objects:

More than 1% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expected

For non-UK objects:

More than 5% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expectedSignificant press interest

reentry_help.content:
Standard re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (National Space Operations Centre, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a priority re-entry alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government departments.

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Satellite_ephemeris_upload.title: Uploading your ephemeris data
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.content:
If you would like updated NSpOC analysis on this conjunction event using your ephemeris data, attach a file below.

If upload is successful, the file will be renamed with the timestamp of the creation date and made available from the Ephemeris table on the satellite information page.

Upload a CCSDS Orbit Ephemeris Message (OEM) file. The file must not exceed 20MB.
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.help_summary: More information about sharing your ephemerides with NSpOC
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.help_content:
Additional analysis will be provided by NSpOC orbital analysts only on conjunction events that NSpOC analysis determines breach a probability of collision ≥ 1e-5

View the terms and conditions for data handling information

Poc_chart.title: Evolution of collision probability
Poc_chart.description: The changing probability of a conjunction event leading up to the time of closest approach (TCA). All available data is shown.

Mtp_chart.description: The probability of collision (PoC) for different combinations of date/time or number of orbits compared to time of closest approach (TCA) and Delta V (amount of burn) of manoeuvre are shown. All available data is shown.

chart.content: This is the maximum PoC you would be prepared to accept after a manoeuvre
chart.title: Probability of collision

details.summary: Help with interpreting manoeuvre trade space plots
details.content:
The plot displays the predicted probability of collision for various possible manoeuvres. These predictions are based on the most recent operational CDM received from Space-Track and analysis conducted by NSpOC.

Reducing the probability of collision typically requires less fuel the further away the time of closest approach is but the probability of collision often decreases over time as more observations are made and data certainty increases. The plot assists operators in determining when and if to perform a manoeuvre by highlighting significant points in time when the probability will change.

All manoeuvres (Delta V) shown are given in the in-track direction.

These predicted probabilities of collision do not take into account any secondary collisions which may occur as a result of manoeuvring.If you wish to determine secondary collision risk, you should upload a Special ephemeris to Space-Track for screening.

Miss_distance.header: The changing expected miss distance leading up to the time of closest approach (TCA). Data from Space-Track is shown.

Events_type.description: Total number of conjunction events monitored between different object types.

Conjunctions.title: Track conjunction events (Monitor your satellites)
Conjunctions.description: This table shows upcoming conjunction events involving UK-licensed satellites by default. You can apply filters to view past events.

search_bar.placeholder: Search by event or object ID

help1.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Upcoming conjunctions</screenReaderOnly>
help1.content:
This service tracks conjunction events for UK-licensed objects.

Conjunction alerts: conjunction events that meet the National Space Operations Centre's thresholds for alerting UK governmentAll conjunction events: all conjunction events, including those which have not met alerting thresholds, either for a specific operator or all UK-licensed satellites

help2.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Conjunction events</screenReaderOnly>
help2.content:
This table shows upcoming conjunction events involving UK-licensed satellites by default. You can apply filters to view past events.

Select the event ID to view more information

Each event ID or row represents one conjunction event including all related Conjunction Data Messages (CDMs) and NSpOC analysis.

The your interest column contains HIGH labels for events that meet your thresholds for notifications.

Conjunction.title: Conjunction event {id}
Conjunction.notification_banner: There is an alert on this event. <preview>View the alert</preview>.

help.title: Help with this chart<screenReaderOnly> - Evolution of collision probability</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
Data sources can be turned on or off by selecting the series in the legend below the chart.

Evolution of operational conjunction event data is displayed as a continuous line. Individual Special ephemeris probabilities can be turned on or off.

You can reveal more details about a specific data point by moving your mouse over it or tapping on the data point on touch-enabled screens.

Full conjunction event data can be viewed or downloaded from Conjunction event history.

help.title: Help with this chart<screenReaderOnly> - Evolution of miss distance</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
Miss distances can be turned on or off by selecting the series in the legend below the chart.

Evolution of operational conjunction event data is displayed as a continuous line. Individual Special ephemeris probabilities can be turned on or off.

You can reveal more details about a specific data point by moving your mouse over it or tapping on the data point on touch-enabled screens.

Full conjunction event data can be viewed or downloaded from Conjunction event history.

additional_object_summary.title: Additional object data
additional_object_summary.content:
ESA DISCOS provides additional object data where available. Contact ESA DISCOS if your satellite data is incorrect.

ESA DISCOS data was last updated on: {updateTime} UTC

Object_data.title: Object Data
Object_data.space_track: Space-Track is the main source of object data. Contact Space-Track if your satellite data is incorrect.

help.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Conjunction event history</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
Historical CDMs for the event are available in this table. Information about the individual CDM is available, including the calculation method for the probability of collision, the position uncertainty and data source for each object.

The data source for each object either comes from SSN observations, special or operational owner/operator ephemeris or NASA/CARA. Further information about these can be found in definitions on data sources.

Further_information.title: Further information
Further_information.description: To understand more about how this data was generated by the NSpOC, see:
Further_information.link2: Help with the information on this page

Conjunction_alert.title: Conjunction alert for {primaryObject} vs {secondaryObject}
Conjunction_alert.notification_banner: You are able to <edit>edit this alert</edit> or <send>send this alert to additional recipients</send>

Executive_summary.title: Conjunction alert summary
Executive_summary.content: The National Space Operations Centre is monitoring the close approach of two objects, <primaryObjectUrl>{primaryObject}</primaryObjectUrl> and <secondaryObjectUrl>{secondaryObject}</secondaryObjectUrl>. A collision could damage the objects involved, limiting or eliminating their capability, as well as releasing new fragments, which would increase the risk of future collisions for other objects. This event is assessed as <tag>{risk}</tag> risk, with a {collisionProbability} probability of collision (PoC).
Executive_summary.closed_report: The National Space Operations Centre has completed monitoring of the conjunction event involving <primaryObjectUrl>{primaryObject}</primaryObjectUrl> and <secondaryObjectUrl>{secondaryObject}</secondaryObjectUrl>, which occurred on {date}. The event was assessed as <tag>{risk}</tag> risk, with a {collisionProbability} probability of collision (PoC).
Executive_summary.see_further_information: See Further information for more detail on methodology used in this report and the organisations that have been sent this alert.

Next_update.title: Next update
Next_update.content: For Low Risk events, updates are only sent if the event breaches a higher risk threshold. For Medium and High Risk events, updates are sent as soon as new information is available. A close-down report will be sent in all cases.

Additional_event_details.potential_increase: Potential increase in future collisions for UK objects (%)
Additional_event_details.see_further_information: See Further information for more detail on methodology used in this report.

immediate_impact.title: Immediate impact
immediate_impact.content: Should the collision occur, it would likely result in a full breakup of both objects. In this worst-case scenario, an estimation of the number of fragments greater than 10cm is {predictedFragments}.

short_term_impact.title: Short term impact
short_term_impact.content: Should the collision occur, the debris would generate an increased risk to satellites. We are predicting that the event would result in an {increaseInFutureCollisions}% increase in potential collisions across all UK satellites.

long_term_impact.title: Long term impact
long_term_impact.content: The collision would occur at an altitude of {altitude} km. The risk from the resulting debris would be sustained for significant periods of time and could eventually impact a broad range of satellites and missions including human spaceflight.

uk_response.title: UK response
uk_response.content: The National Space Operations Centre are the leads for conjunction reporting and have reached out to the operator to confirm they are aware of the event and that they intend to manoeuvre.

press_attention.title: Press attention
press_attention.empty: We have not seen any press attention on this event.

Guidance_on_response.see_press_lines: See <link>National Space Operations Centre press lines</link>.

Additional_risk_to_objects.content:
If a collision between these objects were to occur, the resulting debris may pose additional risk to UK-licensed satellites.

The table below shows how, if this collision were to occur, the number of conjunction events (with a miss distance of 5km or less) for UK-licensed satellites would increase in the following 7 days.

Only the 30 objects with the most predicted additional conjunction events in the week following a collision are shown here.

Operator_view.content: The satellite operator of the UK-licensed object has been notified of the conjunction event via the Monitor space hazards platform. Click to see the information that operators have received.

Alert_thresholds.content:
Standard conjunction alert: If this report is classified as a standard conjunction alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (NSpOC, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office) and international partners.

Priority conjunction alert: If this report is classified as a priority conjunction alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government department.

There are various criteria which determine if alerts are produced about conjunction events. These criteria vary by type of object.

For UK-licensed objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:

More than 0.1% probability of collisionOR press interest

For non-UK objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:

Low risk or higherAND no manoeuvre expected

For all objects:

If nominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Risk_thresholds.content:
Risk thresholds are calculated accounting for the probability of the collision between the two objects (as calculated by Space-Track), and the average number of additional conjunction events that the collision would create for UK satellites.

Any event with an expected maneouvre is automatically categorised as `Low risk`.

methodology.title: Conjunction analysis methodology
methodology.content:
To understand more about how this data was generated by the NSpOC, see:

Conjunction event analysis informationHelp with the information on conjunction events

Conjunction_alert_edit.title: Edit conjunction event for {primaryObject} vs {secondaryObject}
Conjunction_alert_edit.content:
If edits or additions are needed to the automatically generated report, these can be made through free text inputs in the boxes below. Once published, these edits will automatically be added to the relevant event page, and users on the appropriate distribution lists will be notified of the update.

The below boxes can only process plain text. Do not include images or text formatting.

banner.title: Ensure you review before publishing.
banner.content: It is advised that at least two individuals review text edits before they are published on GOV.UK platforms.

Conjunction_alert_send.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Conjunction_alert_send.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the conjunction alert and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the alert a priority conjunction alert. In addition, you can manually select individual emails to send the alert to or send the alert again to other distribution lists.

Reentries.content: This table contains all tracked re-entry events, including re-entry events that meet the National Space Operations Centre's thresholds for alerting UK government. For further detail on how risk and alert thresholds are defined, see 'Help with this table' below.

Reentry.notification_banner: There is an alert on this event. <preview>View the alert</preview>.

Further_information.content: To understand more about how this data was generated by NSpOC, see:
Further_information.help_with_information: Help with the information on re-entry events

Reentry_alert.notification_banner: You are able to <edit>edit this alert</edit> or <send>send this alert to additional recipients</send>
Reentry_alert.title: Re-entry alert for {objectName}

accordion.potential_impact_overseas_territory: Potential impact by British Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies
accordion.potential_impact_airspace_and_maritime: Potential impact by Airspace and Maritime
accordion.guidance_if_object_impacts_uk_interests: Guidance if object impacts UK interests

Executive_summary.title: Event summary
Executive_summary.content: The National Space Operations Centre is monitoring the upcoming re-entry event involving {commonName} from space into Earth's atmosphere, posing a potential risk to life and property on the ground. The event is assessed as <tag>{fragmentsRisk}</tag> risk, with a {fragmentsProbability} probability of debris impacting the UK. The licensing country is {licensingCountry}. All re-entered debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise.
Executive_summary.closed_report: The National Space Operations Centre has completed monitoring of the re-entry event involving {commonName}, which occurred on {date}. The event was assessed as <tag>{fragmentsRisk}</tag> risk, with a {fragmentsProbability} probability of debris impacting the UK. The licensing country is {licensingCountry}. All re-entered debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise.

details.title: Help with this map
details.content:
This map displays the predicted re-entry locations for the object.

This map represents probability distributions and not definitive impact locations. Each spot shows a potential re-entry or debris location from one Monte-Carlo simulation run.

Regions with a higher density of data points indicate higher probability of re-entry or debris at that location, while less dense areas represent lower probability zones.

Re-entry predictions are highly sensitive to changing conditions and subject to change as new tracking data becomes available.

On this map you can:

Zoom and scroll to see potential re-entry locations across the worldToggle to choose the map type, and view areas of interestUse the overflight checkboxes to see overflights of interestClick on a data point to see more information on the scenario

Map.see_further_information: See Further information for more detail on methodology used in this report and the organisations that have been sent this alert.

Next_update.title: Next update
Next_update.content: For Low Risk events, updates are only sent if the event breaches a higher risk threshold. For Medium and High Risk events, updates are sent as soon as new information is available. A close-down report will be sent in all cases.

immediate_response.title: Immediate response
immediate_response.content:
All re-entered debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise. The most commonly used hazardous materials used on spacecraft are:

HydrazineKerosene

Debris objects should not be disposed of nor made available to the public. An appropriate hazmat response (i.e testing by fire service) should take place first.

The National Space Operations Centre is responsible for the monitoring of re-entry of objects from space into Earth's atmosphere, providing warnings and alerts across HM Government. NSpOC will act as subject matter experts, providing advice and guidance on how to deal with the incident. This includes coordinating public communications about the event.

In the event of debris from the re-entry surviving to the ground, local authorities are responsible for any incident response and should follow standard response activities for the damage caused using existing Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) and/or plane crash policies.

Cabinet Office will take on the lead for incident response coordination if the impacts are significant or are across multiple sectors.

recovery_and_clean_up.title: Recovery and clean up
recovery_and_clean_up.content:
Decontamination: If the object is contaminated with hazardous material, it should be decontaminated. Decontamination is led by Defra who are the Lead Government Department for decontamination in England, in liaison with local authorities.

Storage: The object should be sent to storage by a specialist supplier in the local area, as agreed and organised by Defra.

Release: If the object has been declared safe (by Defra), NSpOC will direct it's release to either: MOD Defence Intelligence if the object is of Chinese or Russian origin; the owner of the object or licensing country for the object, organised via the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office; or the Air Accident Investigation Bureau or the Civil Aviation Authority if the object is UK-licensed.

Disposal: If the object cannot be declared safe or decontaminated, it should disposed of as per standard procedures held by Defra.

Incident close down: When departments agree that recovery can be handled through Business As Usual structures, the incident can be closed down. The National Space Operations Centre and Cabinet Office will confirm close down of the event to all parties involved.

risk.low:
This event is assessed as Low risk.

This means it may happen and could have a negative impact on UK interests, but the overall likelihood is low.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, no significant action is required at this stage. Stakeholders should stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre and consider any future updates before taking further action.
risk.medium:
This event is assessed as Medium risk.

This means there is a higher-than-usual chance it could negatively affect UK interests. However, it is still more likely than not to pass without incident.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, no immediate significant action is needed, but stakeholders may consider raising awareness internally. Stakeholders should stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre for updates.
risk.high:
This event is assessed as High risk.

This means there is a significantly higher-than-usual chance it could negatively affect UK interests. However, it is still more likely than not to pass without incident.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, stakeholders should ensure internal awareness, review response plans and stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre for updates.

handling_space_debris.title: Handling Space Debris
handling_space_debris.content:
If space debris survives to the ground, it should be considered hazardous until proven otherwise. Debris must not be disposed of or given to the public. Standard hazardous materials (hazmat) response procedures, such as testing by the fire service, should be followed. Existing local plans for a Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) incident or a plane crash should also be implemented.

The most well-known hazardous substances found in rockets and satellites include:

HydrazineKerosene

The National Space Operations Centre must be informed immediately of any space debris sightings via:

NSpOCIncidents@ukspaceagency.gov.ukResilience@ukspaceagency.gov.ukOrbitalAnalysts@ukspaceagency.gov.uk

public_guidance_on_space_debris.title: Public Guidance on Space Debris
public_guidance_on_space_debris.content:
Space debris can be hazardous and may contain materials that pose a serious risk to health. If you come across an object that you believe to be space debris, follow these steps:

Do not touch the objectNote the location of the objectIf possible, take a photograph of the object without touching itDo not stay close to the objectNotify the authorities by calling 111 (or the relevant number outside the UK)

Space debris remains the property of the spacecraft owner.

If you have already handled an object you believe to be space debris, place it in a safe location where others will not touch it and inform the authorities immediately.

Liability_for_damages.content: {licenseCountry} is liable for any damages and associated costs of the response and recovery efforts caused by the re-entry under the terms of the 1972 Space Liability Convention.

Press_attention.title: Press attention
Press_attention.empty: We have not seen any press attention on this event.

Risk_thresholds.content: Risk thresholds are calculated based on the probability of the debris from the re-entry of the object impacting the UK.
Risk_thresholds.probability_of_ground: Probability of debris impact in UK

details.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Risk thresholds</screenReaderOnly>
details.content:
This table shows the risk thresholds and levels used to assess how a re-entering object could pose a risk to UK interests:

Debris impact in UK: Chance fragments reach the ground within UKRe-entry over UK: Chance the object enters atmosphere over UK

standard_alert.title: Standard re-entry alert
standard_alert.content:
If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (National Space Operations Centre, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

priority_alert.title: Priority re-entry alert
priority_alert.content:
If this report is classified as a priority re-entry alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government departments.

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Reentry_alert_send.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Reentry_alert_send.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the re-entry alert and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the alert a priority re-entry alert. In addition, you can manually select individual emails to send the alert to or send the alert again to other distribution lists.

alert_criteria_help.title: Distribution lists and re-entry alert criteria
alert_criteria_help.content:
Distribution lists:

You are able to view which distribution list users are currently on in the account section (View distribution lists)

Standard re-entry alert

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert:

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Conjunction.special_content: This conjunction event contains information based on potential orbital changes from an unconfirmed manoeuvre, referred to as <special>Special</special> ephemeris. More details on ephemeris can be found in the <link>definitions section</link>.

information_on_calculations.title: Information on calculations
information_on_calculations.content:
Probability of collision values will differ depending on the object sizes and methods used in calculations.

Space-Track uses a radius of 1m, 3m or 5m in their probability calculations. NSpOC orbital analysis uses information on object sizes from ESA DISCOS or a custom value if suitable.

help.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - UK risk probabilities</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
This service tracks all upcoming re-entry events worldwide, including those which pose a risk to the UK. The service reports on two types of re-entry event.

Upcoming risks to UK interests: all upcoming re-entry events that meet the National Space Operations Centre's thresholds for alerting UK governmentUpcoming re-entry events worldwide: all upcoming re-entry events worldwide, including those which have not met alerting thresholds

help.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Risk thresholds</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
This table shows the risk thresholds and levels used to assess how a re-entering object could pose a risk to UK interests:

Debris impact in UK: Chance fragments reach the ground within UKRe-entry over UK: Chance the object enters atmosphere over UK

Add_new_user.help_content:
Admins can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site. Administrators can also view all user accounts for an organisation, and can add new users, and change or delete existing users.

Operators can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site.

Users can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them.

help_reentry.title: Criteria for priority re-entry alerts
help_reentry.content:
Standard re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (National Space Operations Centre, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a priority re-entry alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government departments.

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

help_conjunctions.title: Criteria for priority conjunction alerts
help_conjunctions.content:
Standard conjunction alert

There are various criteria which determine if alerts are produced about conjunction events. These criteria vary by type of object.

For UK-licensed objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest ApproachMore than 0.1% probability of collisionPress interest

For non-UK objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:Low risk or higherNo manoeuvre expected

For all objects:

If nominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority conjunction alert

For UK-licensed objects:

More than 1% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expected

For non-UK objects:

More than 5% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expectedSignificant press interest

help_fragmentation.title: Criteria for priority fragmentation alerts
help_fragmentation.content:
Standard fragmentation alert

There are various criteria which determine if alerts are produced about fragmentation events. These criteria vary by type of object.

For UK-licensed objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest ApproachMore than 0.1% probability of collisionPress interest

For non-UK objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:Low risk or higherNo manoeuvre expected

For all objects:

If nominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority fragmentation alert

For UK-licensed objects:

More than 1% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expected

For non-UK objects:

More than 5% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expectedSignificant press interest

Send_alert.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Send_alert.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the {type} alert and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the alert a priority {type} alert. You are also able to manually select individual emails to send the alert to.

Change_distribution.individually_selected_recipients_hint: If you wish to send the alert to individual recipients not currently receiving alerts, you can do so here.
Change_distribution.individually_selected_recipients_label: Provide individual email addresses to receive alerts about this event in the box below. Separate each email address with a semi-colon.

role_help.content:
Admins can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site. Administrators can also view all user accounts for an organisation, and can add new users, and change or delete existing users.

Operators can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site.

Users can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them.

Emails.sign_in_to_monitor_space_hazards: Sign in to <link>Monitor Space Hazards</link> to view analysis and additional information.
Emails.utc_note: * Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is 1 hour behind British Summer Time (BST) and the same as Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

Reentry_alert.title: {risk} Risk Uncontrolled Re-Entry Alert - Report {reportNumber}
Reentry_alert.utc_note: * Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is 1 hour behind British Summer Time (BST) and the same as Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

Event_information.title: Event Information
Event_information.content:
The National Space Operations Centre is monitoring the uncontrolled re-entry of {commonName}. This {objectType} presents a {fragmentsRisk} risk to life and property on the ground.

{commonName} is expected to re-enter on {date}. This {objectType} has a {riskProbability} probability of debris impacting the UK.

The licensing country is {licensingCountry}.
Event_information.content_closed: The National Space Operations Centre has completed monitoring of the uncontrolled re-entry of {commonName}, which occurred on {date}. The event was assessed as {riskLevel} risk, with a {riskProbability} probability of debris impacting the UK. The licensing country is {licensingCountry}.

risk.low:
This event is assessed as Low risk.

This means it may happen and could have a negative impact on UK interests, but the overall likelihood is low.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, no significant action is required at this stage. Stakeholders should stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre and consider any future updates before taking further action.
risk.medium:
This event is assessed as Medium risk.

This means there is a higher-than-usual chance it could negatively affect UK interests. However, it is still more likely than not to pass without incident.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, no immediate significant action is needed, but stakeholders may consider raising awareness internally. Stakeholders should stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre for updates.
risk.high:
This event is assessed as High risk.

This means there is a significantly higher-than-usual chance it could negatively affect UK interests. However, it is still more likely than not to pass without incident.

Stakeholders are responsible for deciding their own response to this report. In most cases, stakeholders should ensure internal awareness, review response plans and stay engaged with the National Space Operations Centre for updates.

Handling_space_debris.title: Handling Space Debris
Handling_space_debris.content:
Space debris can be hazardous and may contain materials that pose a serious risk to health. All re-entred debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise. This most well-known hazardous substances found in rockets and satellites include Hydrazine and Kerosene.

If space debris survives to the ground, it should be considered hazardous until proven otherwise. Debris must not be disposed of or given to the public. Standard hazardous materials (hazmat) response procedures, such as testing by the fire service, should be followed.

Public_guidance_on_space_debris.title: Public Guidance on Space Debris
Public_guidance_on_space_debris.content:
Space debris can be hazardous and may contain materials that pose a serious risk to health. If you come across an object that you believe to be space debris, follow these steps:

  • Do not touch the object
  • Note the location of the object
  • If possible, take a photograph of the object without touching it
  • Do not stay close to the object
  • Notify the authorities by calling 111 (or the relevant number outside the UK)
  • Space debris remains the property of the spacecraft owner.
  • If you have already handled an object you believe to be space debris, place it in a safe location where others will not touch it and inform the authorities immediately.

Press_attention.title: Press Attention
Press_attention.empty: We are not currently aware of substantive press interest in this event.

Conjunction_alert.title: {risk} Risk Conjunction Alert - Report {reportNumber}
Conjunction_alert.utc_note: * Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is 1 hour behind British Summer Time (BST) and the same as Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

Event_summary.content: The National Space Operations Centre is monitoring the conjunction event {primaryObject} vs {secondaryObject}. A collision could damage the objects involved, limiting or eliminating their capability, as well as releasing new fragments, which would increase the risk of future collisions for other objects. This event is assessed as {risk} risk, with a {probability} probability of collision (PoC).

Event_details.details_content: Sign in to <link>Monitor Space Hazards</link> for more information about this event.
Event_details.event_summary_content: The National Space Operations Centre has completed monitoring the conjunction event {primaryObject} vs {secondaryObject}. A potential collision could have damaged the objects involved, limiting or eliminating their capability, as well as releasing new fragments, which would increase the risk of future collisions for other objects. This event was assessed as {risk} risk, with a {probability} probability of collision (PoC).

Potential_impact_of_event.predicted_number_of_fragments: Predicted Number of Fragments Generated greater than 10cm
Potential_impact_of_event.potential_increase: Potential Increase in Future Collisions for UK Objects

immediate_impact.title: Immediate impact
immediate_impact.content: Should the collision occur, it would likely result in a full breakup of both objects. In this worst-case scenario, an estimation of the number of fragments greater than 10cm is {predictedFragments}.

short_term_impact.title: Short term impact
short_term_impact.content: Should the collision occur, the debris would generate an increased risk to satellites. We are predicting that the event would result in an {increaseInFutureCollisions}% increase in potential collisions across all UK satellites.

long_term_impact.title: Long term impact
long_term_impact.content: The collision would occur at an altitude of {altitude} km. The risk from the resulting debris would be sustained for significant periods of time and could eventually impact a broad range of satellites and missions including human spaceflight.

Recommended_actions.title: Recommended actions
Recommended_actions.content: The National Space Operations Centre are the leads for conjunction reporting and have reached out to the operator to confirm they are aware of the event and that they intend to manoeuvre.

Press_attention.title: Press Attention
Press_attention.empty: We are not currently aware of substantive press interest in this event.

Analysis_upload.title: New NSpOC analysis uploaded
Analysis_upload.content: The National Space Operations Centre (NSpOC) has uploaded new analysis for the following conjunction events involving your satellites. For full information on each event please visit Monitor Space Hazards via the event link.

Conjunction_notification.title: New conjunction event(s)
Conjunction_notification.content: The UK Space Agency's Monitor Space Hazards service has identified new conjunction events involving your satellites and crossing your thresholds. The links to the events and their time of closest approach are listed below.

Conjunction_new_ephemeris.title: Satellite {commonName} : New ephemeris data uploaded
Conjunction_new_ephemeris.content:
A satellite operator has uploaded ephemeris data for satellite {commonName} (NORAD ID: {noradId}).

Sign in to Monitor Space Hazards to view this ephemeris data.

Conjunction_notification_updated.title: Updated conjunction event(s)
Conjunction_notification_updated.content: One or more conjunction events crossing your thresholds has been updated. The links to the events and their time of closest approach are listed below.

Conjunction_notification_new_and_updated.title: New and updated conjunction event(s)
Conjunction_notification_new_and_updated.content: The UK Space Agency's Monitor Space Hazards service has identified new conjunction events involving your satellites and crossing your thresholds. Additionally, one or more conjunction events crossing your thresholds has been updated. The links to the events and their time of closest approach are listed below.

Event_summary.uk_satellites_affected: UK Satellites with Increased Risk of Conjunction

Potential_impact.content: All UK satellites were screened against the current population of objects as well as the fragments generated by the breakup model. The 'Current’ column is the number of 5 km conjunction events the object currently has per week. The 'Predicted' column is the number of additional 5 km conjunction events that would be expected in the 7-day period after the event based on the predicted orbits outputted by the breakup model.

Uk_response.title: UK Response
Uk_response.empty: We are not currently aware of substantive UK response to this event.

Press_attention.title: Press Attention
Press_attention.empty: We are not currently aware of substantive press interest in this event.

Footer.title: Support and Assistance
Footer.content:
For urgent enquiries about this event, email NSPOCincidents@ukspaceagency.gov.uk.

Additional contact details are available via Monitor Space Hazards (for registered users).

We welcome your feedback and ideas to improve future reports. If you're not signed up to Monitor Space Hazards and would like access to the service, please contact us.

Monitor Space Hazards is a service provided by the UK Space Agency via the National Space Operations Centre.
Footer.content_notification:
For assistance in managing an incident, or for more information, please contact our Operations, Analysis and Response Team:

Or email us: NSPOCincidents@ukspaceagency.gov.uk and OrbitalAnalysts@ukspaceagency.gov.uk.

Additional contact details are available via Monitor Space Hazards. Monitor Space Hazards is a service provided by the UK Space Agency via the National Space Operations Centre.
Footer.content_short:
Please direct any questions about this event to nspoc@ukspaceagency.gov.uk

Monitor Space Hazards is a service provided by the UK Space Agency through the National Space Operations Centre.

Fragmentations.title: Track fragmentation events
Fragmentations.description: This table contains all tracked tragmentation events, including fragmentation events that meet the UK Space Agency's thresholds for alerting UK government. For further detail on how risk and alert thresholds are defined, see 'Help with this table' below.

search_bar.placeholder: Search by event or object ID

help.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Fragmentation events</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
This table shows all upcoming and previous tracked fragmentation events that have been identified by Space-Track and ingested into Monitor space hazards, including events which pose a risk to UK satellites and Human Spaceflight missions. Higher risk events contain additional analysis by UKSA's Orbital Analysts at the National Space Operations Centre.

Select the Event ID to view more informationEach Event ID or row represents one fragmentation eventSort the alerts according to criteria by clicking on the relevant headings

Fragmentation.title: Fragmentation event for {object}
Fragmentation.notification_banner: You are able to <edit>edit this alert</edit> or <send>send this alert to additional recipients</send>

Executive_summary.title: Event summary
Executive_summary.content: The event is assessed as <tag>{risk}</tag> risk.
Executive_summary.see_further_information: See Further information for more detail on methodology used in this report and the organisations that have been sent this alert.

Next_update.title: Next update
Next_update.content: A close-down report will be sent for each event.

Fragment_data.title: Fragment data
Fragment_data.content: We've received orbital data for {knownFragments} fragments. The plots below use this cleaned data, based on limited observations. Modelled data is also available for around {modelledFragments} fragments.

help.title: Help with interpreting Gabbard plots
help.content:
The Gabbard plot shows how satellite fragments are distributed in orbit after an event such as a breakup. Each point represents a fragment, plotted by its orbital period (x-axis) and apogee and perigee heights (y-axis). The pattern helps identify how debris spread - fragments close together indicate minor changes in orbit, while wide or crossed patterns suggest a high-energy breakup. In general, points clustered near the parent satellite's orbit show limited dispersion, while wider scatter shows greater variation in altitude and energy.

On this plot you can:

toggle to see distribution of modelled and actual fragment datasee the evolution of the event over time where additional information becomes available

Additional_risk.title: Risk to your assets
Additional_risk.content:
UK satellites affected

All UK satellites were screened against the current population of objects as well as the fragments generated by the breakup model.

help.title: Help with this table
help.content: The 'Current Tally column is the number of 5 km conjunction events the object currently has per week. The 'Fragments Tally' column is the number of additional 5 km conjunction events that would be expected in the 7-day period after the event based on the predicted orbits outputted by the breakup model. Also included in the table is the mass of the licensed object and the orbit information.

Press_attention.title: Press attention
Press_attention.empty: We have not seen any press attention on this event.

Risk_thresholds.title: Risk thresholds
Risk_thresholds.content: Risk thresholds are calculated based on the number of fragments produced.

help.title: Help with this table<screenReaderOnly> - Risk thresholds</screenReaderOnly>
help.content:
This table shows the risk thresholds used to to assess how a fragmentation event could pose a risk

Number of fragments: The number of known fragments produced by the fragmentation event

standard.title: Standard fragmentation alert
standard.content:
If this report is classified as a standard fragmentation alert, then it has been distributed to key UK government organisations (National Space Operations Centre, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority), UK devolved and central government departments and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard fragmentation alert are as follows:

The event involves a UK satelliteThe event generates more than 50 pieces of debris and presents a high risk to UK licensed objects or human spaceflightThe event is likely to generate press interest

priority.title: Priority fragmentation alert
priority.content:
In addition to the standard distribution, the following teams are notified in specific circumstances:

If the licensing country is the UK: Department for Science, Innovation and TechnologyIf there is a potential risk to the International Space Station: UK Space Agency Exploration team

Further_information.help_with_information: Help with the information on fragmentation events

Fragmentation_alert_edit.title: Edit fragmentation event for {object}
Fragmentation_alert_edit.content:
If edits or additions are needed to the automatically generated report, these can be made through free text inputs in the boxes below. Once published, these edits will automatically be added to the relevant event page, and users on the appropriate distribution lists will be notified of the update.

The below boxes can only process plain text. Do not include images or text formatting.
Fragmentation_alert_edit.review_description: Free text edits to fragmentation event {shortId}

banner.title: Ensure you review before publishing.
banner.content: It is advised that at least two individuals review text edits before they are published on GOV.UK platforms.

Fragmentation_alert_send.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Fragmentation_alert_send.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the fragmentation event and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the event a priority fragmentation event. You are also able to manually select individual emails to send the alert to.

alert_criteria_help.title: Distribution lists and fragmentation alert criteria
alert_criteria_help.content:
Distribution lists:

You are able to what distribution list users are currently on in the account section (View distribution lists)

Priority fragmentation alert criteria for automatic distribution:

More than 5% increase in potential collisions with UK satellites and/or Human Spaceflight missionsOR significant press interest

You can use this page to make an event 'priority' before it meets the automatic distribution criteria.
